course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Western Short Stories
course.description: This course will introduce students to representative works of Western short stories produced in the 19th and 20th centuries. It covers some of the most well-known examples from Europe and America, as well as literary works produced in ex-colonies in Africa and South America. The stories selected range in style from realism to fantasy, modernism, and postmodernism. In addition to a critical analysis of themes and the art of fiction writing, students will gain from this course a deeper understanding of human experiences and different outlooks on life characteristic of the western world.

reviews.author: hs
reviews.comment_content:
Works covered:
Spencer Holst, “The Zebra Storyteller”
Alice Munro, “Boys and Girls”
Ernest Hemingway, “Hills Like White Elephants”
Guy de Maupassant, “The Necklace”
Nikolai Gogol, “The Overcoat”
Katherine Mansfield, “The Singing Lesson”
H. Lawrence, “Odours of Chrysanthemum”
William Faulkner, “A Rose for Emily”
Ivan Bunin, “A Cold Autumn”
Franz Kafka, “A Hunger Artist”
Edgar Allen Poe, “The Cask of Amontillado”
Anton Chekov, “The Bet”
Nadine Gordimer, “Home”
Amy Tan, “A Pair of Tickets” (excerpt)
Sandra Cisneros, “The House on Mango Street” (excerpt)
Italo Calvino, “Continuous Cities 2” (excerpt)
Gabriel Garcia Marquez, “A Very Old Man with Enormous Wings”
Ron Carlson, “Grief”
Jamaica Kincaid, “Girl”
Margaret Atwood, “Happy Endings”

Format:
Biweekly lectures where the professor discusses the assigned readings from the previous class (one to two stories).

Assignments:
-Weekly readings (the short stories are mostly under a few pages)
-One group presentation about some common theme in a few stories
-One short essay about some common theme in a selection of stories of your choice (800 word limit)

Attendance:
-Attendance taken
reviews.comment_teaching:
More of a seminar than a lecture: professor is very interactive and will ask students many questions about the text. She also guides the discussion so that we cover all the literary topics in her provided notes. If you don't like to talk in class, this course might be a bit rough for you.

The TA literally contributes nothing aside from taking attendance.
reviews.comment_grading:
Discussion: 15%
Presentation  15%
Writing Assignment (<800 word essay): 30%
Final exam: 40%

Final exam consists of two short answer questions about literary techniques, and one essay similar to the writing assignment. Grading is fair, as long as you listen to instructions and think critically.
reviews.comment_workload: The short stories are relatively straightforward, and online resources are a click away in case you have any doubts about the reading. The 800 word essay is also not bad since you have plenty of time to polish it.

reviews.author: uststudent
reviews.title: Interesting course
reviews.comment_content: It is interesting to read all the stories. Discussion among class about the characters is also fun. A lot of students are very active to answer questions, mainly international, followed by mainlanders, at last locals. You can see some students read as their habit. Others POV and opinions are quite interesting. The messages from the story are meaningful.
reviews.comment_teaching: She is quite encouraging and nice, open to questions. The discussion among students sometimes are quite interesting. Although some ideas are not very reasonable, she still supports students to speak their mind.
reviews.comment_grading: Attend all lessons, did all assignments on my own,  DSE English 5, not good at literature. At last B
reviews.comment_workload:
Around 1 reading per every week, quite relax, you can find sparknotes for more information of the story for a more in-depth understanding. or the plot on wiki as all stories are famous.

Video project, 5-6 people in a group on a chosen topics. You have to create a plot, script for the video filming. The video should demonstrate the characteristics of the characters in different story. At last present your video in front of the class and answer floor questions.

Essay: about a chosen story, for example, a sequel. It would be a bit hard as you need to pretend to be the writer, learning their writing style. Also, The language need to fit time and characters.

reviews.author: anli
reviews.title: pretty good
reviews.comment_content:
- will cover 1 short story each lesson, mostly from Hemingway, mansfield, DH lawrance...
- will analyse the themes and techniques the author used
- totally ok if you have no eng lit background as she will introduce a lot of literary techniques which are useful for both exams and your own reading
- will analyse the story and give you relative background so it's fine even if you don't have any history background
reviews.comment_teaching: Lisa teaches really well and makes the lecture really interesting. She also explains difficult concept with funny and everyday example which makes you learn a lot. However there is almost no notes so you must jot down EVERYTHING she said in class as they are actually what is going to be tested in exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
group project
paper
final exam
participation

you never know what your score is. there is only letter grade for project and paper but no way to know your final exam grade.

she is quite straight with the grading. you really need to put a lot of effort if you want a good grade.

participation is very important!!! make sure you answer questions in class

a lot of exchange students and IB students who have studied lit before so the competition is quite fierce. But if you work hard getting a decent grade is not too difficult.

I have no lit and history background but still get an ok grade (given I didn't participate in class and had no time to study for my final exam) so just go for it for those interested in lit but with no prior knowledge
reviews.comment_workload:
not light at all but not as bad (again if you like eng lit)

need to read the story before class (most of them are short, with a few exceptionally long ones) otherwise you will have no idea what is going on in class

prepare for the project (like a drama): from the perspective of characters in the story or the writers

essay: 1000 words, easy piecey but I guess you need to spend more time on it if you want an A range for it

overall not too bad but this course does take time!

reviews.author: Kalyani
reviews.title: short review
reviews.comment_content: This course consists of 20 short stories being taught over the span of a semester. Their lengths vary and on the whole they can be quite challenging but fun. A background knowledge in literature can prove to be useful but isn't compulsory.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor is engaging and stimulates discussion in class. She provides research references to back her explanations and offers useful worksheets to help students understand the coursework.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fairly lenient. It would greatly help a student to have a higher level of fluency in the English Language to earn a better grade. Participation takes up 15% and thus it is important to answer questions by studying the story assigned before class. In this way, it is easy for the instructor to distinguish who has prepared in advance. An essay question will be given for homework which takes up 30% of the grade.

There's one group project and one final exam which contribute 15% and 40% respectively. Groups are to be formed at the beginning of the semester. The group project consists of using a given theme and explaining it to the class using 3 or more of the short stories. The final exam consists of 2 short questions and 1 essay question.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload can be quite demanding as there are 20 stories to learn. However, proven that time is allocated fairly, it will be manageable. Each week, the students have to prepare the assigned short story before coming to class due to the shortage of time.

reviews.title: High amount of reading and in class discussion
reviews.comment_content:
In class discussion and analysis of short stories, covering the literary techniques.  Most stories are discussed in one lecture each,   some longer ones last 2 lectures.

Story covered:
Spencer Holst, “The Zebra Storyteller”
Alice Munro, “Boys and Girls”

reviews.comment_teaching:
The prof is very nice and interactive. She always ask for opinions and encourage in class discussion.  
However she teach mostly through talking and discussing with students.  The discussion flow and the her points are a bit hard to follow for me, with some very breif notes( 1/2 sentences for one literary technique) and no slides.  You have to take notes for everythin you heard in class, no matter from the teacher or others, otherwise u will remember nothing to use in the essay or in the exam.
The TA is dispensable. He only took attendance.
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Discussion + Participation 15%

2. Presentation 15%
Apply ideas from 4/5 stories studied in this course to conduct an in-depth study of one selected topic:
- The Sense of Home in the Contemporary World
- Morals and Values from Different Perspectives
- Individuals in Historical Contexts
- Human Relationships and Gender Differences

3. Essay  30%
With reference to at least 3 short stories studied in this course, write a 800 word essay to compare the ways in which each author presents a similar theme (choose one from the themes listed below) through the art of fiction writing (such as plot, narrative structure, narrative point-of-view, characterization, setting and symbol).

4. Examination 40%
-  4-5 SQs on literary styles and techniques
-  LQ (essay question) on selected discussion topics (similar to the assignment)
- To answer each question, u need to state examples for stories studied in the course. Cannot use the same story for more than one question.  ( needs a lot memorizations)


I got a B- for presentation and a B for the essay. I dont know the marks for the final and I didnt participant much in class. I got a C+ overall.  

Note that my group mates got diff grades for the presentation, one got a B+ and one got a C+.  So the individual Q&A is also important.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is extremely high for me.
  
You are expected to read the story in detail before attending the class, otherwise u cannot follow the discussion. Those short stories can be  2 pages or over 30 pages.  Most storied covered are over 15 pages. So it requires a high amount of reading.  It was a bit hard for me since my English is not good enough.

Workload for the essay and the presentation is fair.

Preparing the final is tiring for me. u have to memorize all the techniques used in each stories in order to answer the questions.  Therefore u need to fully understand what each stories is talking about and what techniques they used.
